question: In a network with dozens of switches, how many root bridges would you have?
answer_description: You should have only one root bridge per network.

question: How to implement a network medium that is not susceptible to EMI. Which type of cabling should you use?
answer_description: Fiber-optic cable provides a more secure, long-distance cable that is not susceptible to EMI interference at high speeds.

question: What type of RJ45 UTP cable do you use to connect a PC's COM port to a router or switch console port?
answer_description: To connect to a router or switch console port, you would use an RJ45 UTP rolled cable.

question: Which of the following describe the DHCP Discover message?It usesFF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FFas a layer 2 broadcast.It uses UDP as the Transport layer protocol.It uses TCP as the Transport layer protocol.It does not use a layer 2 destination address.
answer_description: A client that sends out a DHCP Discover message in order to receive an IP address sends out a broadcast at both layer 2 and layer 3. The layer 2 broadcast is all Fs in hex, orFF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF. The layer 3 broadcast is255.255.255.255, which means all networks and all hosts. DHCP is connectionless, which means it uses User Datagram Protocol (UDP) at the Transport layer, also called the Host-to-Host layer.

question: What is the maximum number of IP addresses that can be assigned to hosts on a local subnet that uses the 255.255.255.224 subnet mask?
answer_description: A /27 (255.255.255.224) is 3 bits on and 5 bits off. This provides 8 subnets, each with 30 hosts. Does it matter if this mask is used with a Class A, B, or C network address? Not at all. The number of host bits would never change.

question: You have an interface on a router with the IP address of 192.168.192.10/29. Including the router interface, how many hosts can have IP addresses on the LAN attached to the router interface?
answer_description: A /29 (255.255.255.248), regardless of the class of address, has only 3 host bits. Six hosts is the maximum number of hosts on this LAN, including the router interface.

question: You telnet to a router and make your necessary changes; now you want to end the Telnet session. What command do you type in?
answer_description: Since the question never mentioned anything about a suspended session, you can assume that the Telnet session is still open, and you would just typeexitto close the session.

question: IGRP uses which of the following as default parameters for finding the best path to a remote network?Hop countMTUCumulative interface delaySTPPath bandwidth value
answer_description: IGRP uses bandwidth and delay of the line, by default, to determine the best path to a remote network. Delay of the line can sometimes be called the cumulative interface delay.

question: What are the distinct functions of layer 2 switching that increase available bandwidth on the network?Address learningRoutingForwarding and filteringCreating network loopsLoop avoidanceIP addressing
answer_description: Layer 2 features include address learning, forwarding and filtering of the network, and loop avoidance.

question: If you want to disable STP on a port connected to a server, which command would you use?
answer_description: If you have a server or other devices connected into your switch that you're totally sure won't create a switching loop if STP is disabled, you can use something calledportfaston these ports. Using it means the port won't spend the usual 50 seconds to come up while STP is converging.

question: Which of the following is true regarding VLANs?

options.A: You must have at least two VLANs defined in every Cisco switched network.
options.B: All VLANs are configured at the fastest switch and, by default, propagate this information to all other switches.
options.C: You should not have more than 10 switches in the same VTP domain.
options.D: VTP is used to send VLAN information to switches in a configured VTP domain.

answer_description: Switches do not propagate VLAN information by default; you must configure the VTP domain. VLAN Trunk Protocol (VTP) is used to propagate VLAN information across a trunked link.

question: Which switching technology reduces the size of a broadcast domain?
answer_description: Virtual LANs break up broadcast domains in layer 2 switched internetworks.

question: Which of the following is an IEEE standard for frame tagging?
answer_description: 802.1Q was created to allow trunked links between disparate switches.

question: You connect a host to a switch port, but the new host cannot log into the server that is plugged into the same switch. What could the problem be?

options.A: The router is not configured for the new host.
options.B: The VTP configuration on the switch is not updated for the new host.
options.C: The host has an invalid MAC address.
options.D: The switch port the host is connected to is not configured to the correct VLAN membership.

answer_description: This question is a little vague, but the best answer is that the VLAN membership for the port is not configured.

question: If you wanted to deny FTP access from network 200.200.10.0 to network 200.199.11.0 but allow everything else, which of the following command strings is valid?

options.A: access-list 110 deny 200.200.10.0 to network 200.199.11.0 eq ftpaccess-list 111 permit ip any 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255

answer_description: Extended IP access lists use numbers 100-199 and 2000-2699 and filter based on source and destination IP address, protocol number, and port number. The last option is correct because of the second line that specifies permit ip any any. (I used 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255, which is the same as the any option.) The third option does not have this, so it would deny access but not allow everything else.

question: What is the maximum distance running the lowest data rate for 802.11g?
answer_description: The IEEE 802.11g standard's lowest data rate is 6Mbps, but it can run from a distance of about 300 feet.

question: You have a Cisco mesh network. What protocol allows multiple APs to connect with many redundant connections between nodes?
answer_description: Each AP in a mesh network runs the Adaptive Wireless Path Protocol (AWPP). This protocol allows RAPs to communicate with each other to determine the best path back to the wired network via the RAP.

question: Which of the following is true when describing a global unicast address?

options.A: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
options.B: These are your typical publicly routable addresses, just like a regular publicly routable address in IPv4.
options.C: These are like private addresses in IPv4 in that they are not meant to be routed.
options.D: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.

answer_description: Unlike unicast addresses, global unicast addresses are meant to be routed.

question: Which encapsulations can be configured on a serial interface?EthernetToken RingHDLCFrame RelayPPP
answer_description: Ethernet and Token Ring are LAN technologies and cannot be configured on a serial interface. PPP, HDLC, and Frame Relay are layer 2 WAN technologies that are typically configured on a serial interface.

question: In which of the following technologies is the term HFC used?
answer_description: In a modern network, hybrid fibre-coaxial (HFC) is a telecommunications industry term for a network that incorporates both optical fiber and coaxial cable to create a broadband network.
